name: 1598_C. Delete Two Elements
description:
Monocarp has got an array a consisting of n integers. Let's denote k as the mathematic mean of these elements (note that it's possible that k is not an integer). 

The mathematic mean of an array of n elements is the sum of elements divided by the number of these elements (i. e. sum divided by n).

Monocarp wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mathematic mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still equal to k.

Your task is to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.

The mathematic mean of an array of n elements is the sum of elements divided by the number of these elements. In other words, it’s the total sum divided by n. Monocarp wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mathematic mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still equal to k. Your task is to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a). Ensure your implementation considers edge cases for arrays with fewer than three elements where no valid pair can be formed.

Monocarp has an array a with n integers. The mean, k, of these elements is calculated by dividing the sum of the elements by the number of elements. He wants to remove two elements from the array such that the mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still k. The task is to find the number of pairs [i, j] (where i < j) in the array that, when removed, result in the mean of the remaining elements being equal to k. It's important to handle edge cases where the array has fewer than three elements, as no valid pairs can exist in such cases

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.
Write a main() function and use input() function to read input from stdin

Monocarp has an array a of n integers. The mean k of these elements is calculated as the sum of elements divided by the number of elements. He wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still k. Calculate the number of pairs [i, j] (i < j) such that deleting the elements at these positions keeps the mean of the remaining elements equal to k. Consider edge cases for arrays with fewer than three elements.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.
Write a main() function and use input() function to read input from stdin
completions:
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List

def calculate_pairs(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    if n < 3:
        return 0
    
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean = total_sum / n
    
    count = 0
    
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            if i != j:
                new_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
                new_mean = new_sum / (n - 2)
                if new_mean == mean:
                    count += 1
    
    return count

# Interface
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = calculate_pairs(n, arr)
    print(result)

from typing import List
## main.py

def find_valid_pairs(n, arr):
    if n < 3:
        return 0
    
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    original_mean = total_sum / n
    
    valid_pairs_count = 0
    element_count = {}
    
    # Count the occurrences of each element
    for num in arr:
        if num in element_count:
            element_count[num] += 1
        else:
            element_count[num] = 1
    
    # Iterate through all possible pairs
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            if i != j:
                # Calculate the sum of the remaining elements
                remaining_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
                remaining_count = n - 2
                # Calculate the mean of the remaining elements
                remaining_mean = remaining_sum / remaining_count
                # Check if the remaining mean is equal to the original mean
                if remaining_mean == original_mean:
                    valid_pairs_count += 1
    
    return valid_pairs_count

# Provide the Interface
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = find_valid_pairs(n, arr)
    print(result)

from typing import List
from typing import List

def find_pairs(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    # Calculate the mean of the array
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean = total_sum / n
    
    # Initialize the result counter
    result = 0
    
    # Iterate through all possible pairs of indices (i, j) where i < j
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            # Calculate the new sum after removing elements at indices i and j
            new_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
            # Calculate the new mean
            new_mean = new_sum / (n - 2)
            # Check if the new mean is equal to the original mean
            if new_mean == mean:
                result += 1
    
    return result

from typing import List

def calculate_pairs(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    original_mean = sum(arr) / n
    count_pairs = 0
    sum_arr = sum(arr)

    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            remaining_sum = sum_arr - arr[i] - arr[j]
            remaining_count = n - 2
            if remaining_sum / remaining_count == original_mean:
                count_pairs += 1

    return count_pairs

def calculate_pairs(n, arr):
    # Calculate the original mean of the array
    original_sum = sum(arr)
    original_mean = original_sum / n
    
    # Initialize the count of valid pairs
    count = 0
    
    # Iterate through all possible pairs [i, j] where i < j
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            # Calculate the sum of the remaining elements after deleting arr[i] and arr[j]
            remaining_sum = original_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
            remaining_count = n - 2
            remaining_mean = remaining_sum / remaining_count
            
            # Check if the mean of the remaining elements is still equal to the original mean
            if remaining_mean == original_mean:
                count += 1
    
    return count

from typing import List
from typing import List

def calculate_pairs(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean = total_sum / n
    
    count = 0
    
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            new_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
            new_n = n - 2
            if new_n > 0 and new_sum / new_n == mean:
                count += 1
    
    return count

# Interface
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = calculate_pairs(n, arr)
    print(result)

requirement analysis:
The requirement is to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] such that deleting the elements at these positions results in the remaining elements having the same mean as the original array. The solution must handle multiple test cases efficiently, considering the constraints on the number of elements and test cases.
requirement pool:
- Implement a function to calculate the mean of the array
- Find pairs of positions [i, j] such that deleting elements at these positions maintains the mean
- Optimize the solution for large inputs
- Handle edge cases where no valid pairs exist
- Ensure the solution is clear and easy to understand
To solve this problem efficiently, we will use Python due to its powerful standard libraries and ability to handle large datasets. The approach involves calculating the mean of the array and then iterating through all possible pairs of indices to check if removing those elements results in the remaining elements having the same mean. We will optimize this by avoiding unnecessary calculations and leveraging set operations for quick lookups.
Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
 # [core concept]
    'mathematic mean': the average of a set of numbers, calculated by dividing the sum of the numbers by the count of the numbers.
    Explanation: In this problem, we need to find pairs of indices [i, j] such that removing the elements at these indices results in the remaining elements having the same mean as the original array.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'exactly two elements': means we need to remove two specific elements from the array.
    Explanation: We need to identify pairs of indices [i, j] where i < j, and removing the elements at these indices will not affect the mean of the remaining elements.

# [degree adverb] 
    'exactly': means we need to find pairs of indices that meet the condition without any deviation.
    Explanation: We need to ensure that the mean of the remaining elements after removing two specific elements is exactly the same as the original mean.

# [code logic]
    (check if there are steps should be considered simultaneously)
    To implement this, we will follow these steps:
    1. Calculate the mean of the entire array.
    2. Iterate through all possible pairs of indices [i, j] where i < j.
    3. For each pair, calculate the new mean of the remaining elements.
    4. Check if the new mean is equal to the original mean.
    5. Count the number of such pairs.

# [edge case] 
    Edge case 1: Array with fewer than three elements.
    search([1, 2]) = 0
    Explanation: Since there are fewer than three elements, it's impossible to remove two elements and still have a mean. Therefore, the number of pairs is 0.

    Edge case 2: Array where all elements are the same.
    search([5, 5, 5]) = 3
    Explanation: There are three pairs [0, 1], [0, 2], and [1, 2] that can be removed to maintain the same mean.

    Edge case 3: Array where no pair can satisfy the condition.
    search([1, 2, 3]) = 0
    Explanation: The mean of the array is 2, but no pair of elements can be removed to maintain this mean. Therefore, the number of pairs is 0.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The logic provided in the plan is sufficient to handle all cases.

 # [core concept]
    'mathematic mean': The average value of a set of numbers, calculated by dividing the sum of the numbers by the count of the numbers.
    Explanation: In this problem, we need to find pairs of indices [i, j] such that deleting the elements at these indices does not change the mean of the remaining elements. The mean of the entire array is calculated and used as a reference to check if deleting specific pairs maintains this mean.

    'exactly two elements': This phrase indicates that we need to remove two specific elements from the array to check if the mean remains unchanged.
    Explanation: The requirement specifies that we need to delete exactly two elements from the array to evaluate if the mean of the remaining elements is still equal to the original mean.

# [degree adverb] 
    'exactly': This adverb indicates that we need to find pairs of indices that, when removed, result in the mean of the remaining elements being exactly the same as the original mean.
    Explanation: The use of 'exactly' emphasizes the need for precision in identifying pairs of indices that, when removed, do not alter the mean of the array.

# [code logic]
    (check if there are steps should be considered simultaneously)
    To solve this problem, we will follow these steps:
    1. Calculate the mean of the entire array.
    2. Iterate through all possible pairs of indices [i, j] where i < j.
    3. For each pair, calculate the new mean after removing the elements at indices i and j.
    4. Count the number of pairs that result in a mean equal to the original mean.
    5. Return the count of such pairs.

# [edge case] 
    Edge case 1: Array with fewer than three elements.
    search([1, 2]) = 0
    Explanation: Since there are fewer than three elements, it is impossible to remove exactly two elements to maintain the mean. Therefore, the expected output is 0.

    Edge case 2: Array where all elements are the same.
    search([5, 5, 5]) = 3
    Explanation: In this case, removing any two elements will not change the mean. There are three possible pairs: [0, 1], [0, 2], and [1, 2].

    Edge case 3: Array where no pair can maintain the mean.
    search([1, 2, 3]) = 0
    Explanation: The mean of the array is 2, and no pair of elements can be removed to maintain this mean. Therefore, the expected output is 0.

examples:
Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.
